ZRuHMqTzq3kRSZAPddriiQ.text: Great for grilled seafood, chicken wings and oyster omelettes. I sat back on a lazy Sunday afternoon with a few beers and some grilled tiger prawns. Yes, this was a great way to spend a Sunday afternoon and yes it was more expensive than you would expect. For a safe option and good street food Newton is the way to go.

ZQtdO0NuTEpU-t5aCNi6uQ.text: This is one of the well-known hawker centres among tourists so the prices are a bit higher and some of the stall owners may target tourists, sometime overly pushy and annoying.  But as long as you learn to politely and firmly stand your ground, that's not a problem and the food offerings are quite good.  My fav includes black pepper crab, sambal stingray cooked in banana leaf, and kang kong (morning glory).It looks clean and well maintained, even when we visited late at night (actually early in the morning).  I'd recommend this place to friends who are visiting Singapore.

X3s6mVvulOsURN99UiUssA.text: Duck rice at the front store was pretty decent. Avocado juice at the fruit juice store in the front, next door was terrible. Tasted like dishwater, couldn't drink more than a mouthful. Not sure if it's just what the taste is like, or because I didn't add milk / sugar. Maybe I should have asked for an avocado shake? Nevertheless, wouldn't order again.

mqdtljte4Q18pdfK5hzkxg.text: a nice place to eat. obviously touristy and the prices reflect that. i thought it was a bit expensive for what we got but the food was pretty good. w had some large garlic prawns, roti, an oyster pancake and all were great. we didn't eat that much bit still went away $60 less in our pocket for two people.

dnqJVCLGBj7eQ3sHs3m7rg.text: OK, so locals will call me a tourist for this review, but hey I am. Newton is great for quality, cheap local food. We loved #56 Newton's Grill - the crispy prawns are gobsmackingly yummy, and Stanley at #66 is a hoot. Get in there.

SabVk1qM01ixn_DH1cCfjQ.text: Newton Hawker Center is a short distance from Newton MRT station and is reputed to be a "tourist trap". Complaints range from exorbitant prices for seafood to mediocre food quality.I do like some of the stalls there though - the carrot cake is good and fish soup is also reputedly good. Also, I had seafood (I just picked some random stall) and it was quite good, though yes, it was expensive. What can get annoying about this place are the "touts" that keep bugging you to order from their stall. So, while I don't have a specific stall to recommend, and it is not my favourite hawker centre, I'd suggest heading down if you're in the area and feel like local fare. It's really not that bad , and not that expensive. As for which stall to choose, I'd recommend the standard method of looking for a queue ... shouldn't be far off decent food then!

Rq_aK8jgF8XoGEE13MNmxw.text: Everything I've had here has been pretty solid. Nothing has stood out particularly but nothing was bad at the same time. The location is very convenient, and this is one of the nicer hawker centers in Singapore. It is a little pricier than others though.

WodFvwRWrx-6UBf4SLa-xg.text: I can absolutely recommend you this place if you're visiting Singapore as a tourist. The famous Hawker food can be found here in an atmosphere that is appealing also for first-timers. Of course it's not cheap, of course the locals go to other places less popular with foreigners. But those are impossible to find if you're not accompanied by a local and not everybody from abroad will like it there. So, Newton Food Center has it all, a wide choice of tasty quality food, most typical local dishes and a nice atmosphere. I recommend particularly the Goodman BBQ seafood grill (see picture). Try the spicy squid or the BBQ stingray! And of course: tiger beer :-)))

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

FOgsD2G7Hw_00hg6-ekzTg.text: One word - over-rated! I don't really like coming here as you get 'accosted' by all the vendors from different stalls shoving their menus in your faces. The food here isn't' really that great to be honest and is your standard hawker food, albeit at much higher prices. If you do have to come here eat, just ignore the vendors and choose your own seat. There are a couple of stalls here that serve better food, but they tend to close early and on weekends. The stalls on the outer ring are generally less crowded and the food isn't as good as well.

cm9aLZ0x1KyY0FXWzzci8Q.text: Coming here I will always get three types of foods from three stores. Cheng teng ( a type of Chinese desert where there is shaved ice which melts with the other ingredients) from the front left first store, satay from the middle row - Bee Heng, and hokkien prawn noodles from the middle front row - Kwang Huat. The prawn noodles owner will only open after 7.45pm on most days and if you come here earlier than that the store will be closed. I'm not sure what time they open for lunch. These are the three recommended stores in Newton food center. Hope you like as much as I do :)

61FIA3wxK6Rj7bevEZpuLQ.text: My dining experience here was not pleasant at all. It was late at night, and I was tired and hungry, and using what was left of my energy to explain the different hawker foods to a friend from overseas that I was showing around. I did not appreciate the hawkers bugging us at all. They came at us at first warmly, insisting on showing us which table to sit at, then kept shoving the menu at us insisting we order something. When we said we wanted to look around first so that I could show him the different foods, they would insist that all the food around is the same so I might as well get it from them. This happened at every seafood stall of which there was one every two stalls or so. It got so bad that we walked around from afar and would only approach a stall if it did not say seafood.And then, there's the price. It is probably about 20% to 50% more than what the food would usually cost in an average hawker centre. A plate of duck rice or fish porridge would probably be $4 and drinks were $2.50 to $3. I didn't think the duck rice was very good to be honest and had far too much sauce on it and not enough duck. The fish porridge was quite decent, and the popiah was rather bland. If you desperately need a place to eat like we did, then I suppose this is not too bad an option but otherwise, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone at all.

r1A1_3Lg0KoK92vYfJGpXQ.text: there's a ton of seafood options here and prices can get a bit steep for a hawker center.. we got the sambal stingray which was meh.. i could probably never have that again.. maybe because it had way too many bones.. the mutton murtabak was pretty damn heavy.. tasty.. but definitely share this.. pro-tip.. get a table.. throw something down to mark it (e.g. napkins).. and go running around and ordering... they will bring the food to your table.. this place did seem to have a lots of tourists the one time i came..

5WLalJNu7MyeyFEOzvNNIw.text: I'll take a moment to reiterate what the earlier reviews have said - prices here are not of the typical hawker centre - and most of the stalls hardly have the quality of, let's say, Ghim Moh Hawker Centre or Tiong Bahru Hawker, and it annoys me that they use styrofoam plates and disposable chopsticks for meals here. Portions are small, food is at least 40% more expensive, and the hawkers are so ravenous for money that they've lost the charming homeliness that most Singaporeans have become accustomed to.

JEvWqtPVWMcwLO4byHsPGg.text: Newton is the probably the most famous hawker centre in Singapore. For lack of better options, it's the place that I bring my tourist friends to eat at when they're in town. Yes I know that Newton is terribly touristy and can be a bit overpriced - but in terms of location though, it's hard to beat it. Maxwell is much quieter at night, and Chomp Chomp is just too far away. Seafood at Newton can be expensive if you're not careful about what you order - but there are some gems in the centre. Try looking for the famous carrot cake shop - it's the one with the super long queue (yeah, exactly the best descriptor I know). Other must tries include a really yummy Hokkien Mee (again, not sure where it is exactly, but the store does have a few newspaper cuttings in front of it). It's

9kOvWtKZoLL_qesCNq70ww.text: well it it pretty neat and it gets way to crowded.

-2WwP4yNd9ukRHCws7kCyA.text: Good food. Wide selection. A bit pushy with the vendors selling their food. Just walk around and get what looks good to you.

nqCvptcShCoBYon8iRwjjg.text: I've been to over 25 countries and I'm pretty open to trying anything, and I definitely value taste over atmosphere.  I really liked this place.  I didn't find them too pushy.  A local taught me to just go with whomever seats you and then go ahead and order from them.  True you may not get your ideal restaurant that way, but instead of resisting the person you just go with the flow, and all the food there is good anyways. The stingray is delicious, much more meaty than another place I used to go near the Hilton hotel where I normally stay.  It's all a little pricey, but it's cheaper than ordering in fancy restaurant and it tastes a lot better.  What's not to like? They also have really good fruit juices there, such as the fresh young coconut (make sure to specify YOUNG coconut - the old ones are a lot bigger but don't taste good).  Another nice thing about this place is nobody is allowed to smoke, even though it's an open area outside.

CKx4CUxx54oQJbsiYR4aqw.text: not as impressed with this food centre since most of the stalls were closed during the lunch day.  think it's more of a late night place.  had some duck rice (was a little overrated) and moved on.  this is one of those places you have to be careful about how much they charge you for the seafood.

_gzZwo8ed23lSDXKC5VheA.text: Be careful about this place.Lot of touting goes on and prices are not cheap.This is suppose to be halker centre and there are many stories for tourist been taken for a ride.This place a developed a bad reputaion

zgM4H4Afc6MpTxedcdgXtg.text: One of the better food courts in Singapore and in open air. Excellent seafoods and all the usual food (chicken wings, Indian, Hong Kong, Thai- you name it) and at very affordable prices. To get there, either take the MRT to Newton Circle or take a cab.

Uvi2yo2i6b1jSiDP5HKBjg.text: Do you like char kway teow? Because if you do, it is delicious and plentiful here. As is the hokkien mee. Wash it down with some sugarcane juice. Seriously, you have no excuse because this place is right by the Newton MRT stop. Enjoy that your wallet continues to feel as heavy as your stomach. Rinse and repeat.

4ZXp2O8uzW07pVp5I47EjQ.text: Easy go-to place for all varieties of hawker food. My fav are satays, seafood and oyster eggs. Though it's always crowded there are plenty of seats, very clean and you can share tables. For tourists they will sell to you in bigger portions....

QYwm2nurlK1Zom_G0TY9nQ.text: Pros: lots of selection, centrally located, cheap (for Singapore) beer, nice outdoor atmosphere.Cons: a tad touristy, but under the right circumstances that can be a pro.This is a good night out for visiting friends who want something a bit different than MBS and it's scene. It's more authentic dining than a posh restaurant often turns out and you will spend about a third of the cost.

xiN4NBr4SzcMlaavOtMMSg.text: My husband took me here for my first hawker experience and it was pretty neat! We went on a Sunday evening, and it wasn't crowded at all.Certainly not the best food I've ever tasted, but an experience that can't be replicated in the US, for sure.I had prawn noodles from the Tian Xiang Big Prawn Noodle stall for $5 and it was aiiiight. Paired with sugar cane water that was sold from the stall next door, it was a pretty decent meal. Locals may complain about the price, but coming from NYC I found it to be easy on the wallet. The vendors approaching us constantly (even when we already had our food ordered) was a minor inconvenience, but again, NYC has trained me well in ignoring people so I didn't mind it too much. Just politely decline and they'll leave you alone. Trust me, it could be A LOT worse- at least they don't repeatedly bother you after you've said "no" once.Overall, not a bad place to visit, good to say you've been once.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. My $5 bowl of prawn noodle soup

v9Fm_CvHHIt0z3d4KdMzXg.text: The food here was GREAT. But clearly no one else is in love with this place so maybe it's just because I'm a white girl from California and it was one of my first meals in Singapore, or maybe it's because my friends who took me here who are from Singapore handled all of the ordering for us so it wasn't as overwhelming as others say.We tried the fried carrot cake, satay, seafood fried rice, chicken wings, bok choy, popiah, and drank endless gallons of lime juice. Everything that was ordered was AWESOME. Nothing was just "ok". I would highly recommend this spot if you're with people who know what to order from which stall! Also the ambiance was fun at night when we went.

Q0b_4dbG9-ZnrUZfJRCv4w.text: A staple among locals, and a must-see for tourists, Newton Hawker Center is a bustling metropolis of hawker stalls that form a double-sided circle, with a quadrangle of seating in the middle. Known for their authentic local fare, impressive variety of foods, and aggressive touters, this is definitely a historical Singaporean landmark. You will inevitably be spoilt for choice as you (attempt to) peruse the neon signboard menus, and try to fend off laminated menu wielding waiters. But fear not, it is more difficult to find bad food here than good. Chances are, you'll like what you get, and will want to return for more.  Just be wary of sneaky seafood stalls that try to oversell or overcharge for their goods! I advise you to demand a final price quote before sitting down and agreeing to eat at any particular hawker. The good ones will give you a straight answer, and even weigh the seafood in front of you.Must tries:Chili or Black Pepper Crab with fried bunsSambal StingrayBarbecued Crayfish/Tiger PrawnsHokkien MeeCarrot Cake (black is fried with soy sauce, white is fried with egg)Chicken RiceChar Kway Teow RojakPrata (plain or with egg are traditional)Ice Kachang dessertSugarcane Juice (with or without lemon)Teh Tarik (pulled tea)Milo Dinosaur

tTzF70ldthJ6ScSsEVzBjw.text: Chili crab, black pepper crab, spicy squid, Succulent fish, prawns, chicken currys....need I say more? There are countless vendors to choose from but they all have a similar taste and it's all good food. Definitely a bit pricier than other similar establishments (as it's more of a touristy spot) but the food you can't go wrong with. The only thing I would say is not to go for any of the chicken tikka's or tandoori chicken as they were very dry and extremely standard...in other words, you can do a better tikka at home...the naan's though were out of this world!!!! Spicy/chili squid and black pepper crab are a must try!

8Azo3jQgY7b1X0Iq_k76fQ.text: This place closed down and I understand is going to get torn down for new development.  Don't waste your time and money coming here

JOppJmaRLi_8Xw_x0GLPxw.text: Over the last few years in Singapore we have eaten here about half a dozen times. The first time we arrived it was mayhem as stall owners fought you to come and eat at their stall. All that is except one. At unit 70 stood one gem in among the sea of sales pitches. Ms Tan at unit 70 simply said take a look at the others and come back and see me. We did, and over the years have tried the tiger prawns in many forms, Sambal sting ray, BBQ red snapper, various veggie dishes and the Singapore noodles. Without exception all were very very good.Ms Tan herself is one in a million. Every time a dish arrives she will say" yummy yummy in your tummy". It never fails to bring a smile.

PgJGz1tsa4gKdzG6vpJGdQ.text: This is a good place to go if you want seafood (think chilli crab, grilled stingray and cereal prawns) in a less formal environment than say Jumbo Seafood. I lost count but there must be 10 seafood stalls here!! So grab some seafood and a fruit drink and who cares if people label you as a tourist?Prices aren't cheap for Asia but still cheaper than for those from Australia etcThere are plenty of tables and if you go outside of peak times, it shouldn't be too much of an issue finding a seat.Newton Circus is only a short walk from the Newton MRT station. TIP no need to walk over the pedestrian bridge, go further along and cross at the traffic light leading into the carpark.

YeCbYvbKk32FnJtypClRqA.text: Very cool experience & a must do in Singapore. Aggressive vendors which can be weird so be sure to take time & browse & get some stuff from different places.Get the stingray & the chili crab, both are completely amazing!

NWKfebFPSdAoKyzmBAlrWg.text: Yommeh ! Hawker style seafood with restaurant level price (beware of how much you order!) . I'd say the food was great. For a group of six we ate like kings.  Tried the grilled stingray, oyster omelette (so good!), chilli squid, chilli clams, kang kung belacan, beansprouts, grilled chicken wings, and a few others. The dishes were quite delicious. Everything went inside my mouth without any problems. I'd say go with a group of friends to be able to order more.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Finding Nemo (found! )

ul4anSYJnRpE6sfylp45fQ.text: Great location with a variety of restaurants. I had Indian food which was cheap and delicious! Lots of flavor. My wife on the other hand was tricked by a vendor standing outside one of the restaurants to order, prawns, stingray, noodles, rice and fish. When I asked her how much the bill was, she was uncertain. We asked the vendor, and he tells us, not to worry that it's cheap and we get a lot of food at a great deal. At the end of eating her meal, the guy who tricked my wife, tells us the bill is $130 Singapore dollars!! Say What??? I didn't have that much Singapore dollars on me and only had a $100 US dollar bill  which the vendor gladly took to compensate for the Singapore dollars. Tourists, please be careful when coming here! The food is good, but avoid the vendors that come up to you to try to get you to go to their restaurant. Do it on your own. Plenty of places to choose from and not as expensive! Three stars for the food. Loss of two stars for the tricky vendors praying upon tourists.

DihHawa6So9l7FLa3CqCFw.text: Want to taste a bite of everything? This is the place to be! I couldn't recomment hust one stand, but go for fish and veggi's. To my humble oppinion those were the best.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

jG8qZmSQMEEnqWCvBVVvQQ.text: I think my expectations were too high for the place, and maybe I was tired, but I just found newton a bit too aggressive, noticeably more expensive, and lacking diversity in the menu options. Disclaimer: We did go on Vesak day and some stalls were closed.We went with a mee goreng, a lemon chicken (seemed pricey at $15?), and an oyster sauce green vege dish. Had the bean curd for dessert. Everything was just average I thought. The lemon chicken probably the best dish but I should hope so at $15 in a hawker centre! I would have liked to have seen some more noodle and rice options...maybe I hadn't done my research well enough? Because I know this place gets good kudos. It was the hard sell from the stall owners that really put me off though.Meh, won't be back.

MyLtJyPjFIyOScAhOLd5Gw.text: I am a pretty picky eater, but thanks to a work trip to Singapore (and a foodie co-worker), I was taken here one night during a recent trip... well, actually we went back the next night too ;)I was staying just down the road at the Sheraton and walked there.  The place I decided to eat at was just in side the corner entrance to the right - maybe the 3rd place in?  For the first time in my life, I had stingray.  I was pleasantly surprised at the flavor and size of the portion!  Can't wait to go back!

n5NrMqdb-NLtDtCRREQ8Ig.text: Disclaimer: I went WITH THE LOCALS!!!My colleague's uncle actually owns a shop in this food centre. So, as you can probably guess, we ordered everything from his shop. (I think.)I have no idea what the communication was, but the food was all great. Black and white carrot cakesStingraysalted (but actually sweet) fried calamarichili crabbansal something (forgot the name, it was the spicy version)chicken wingsshell fish where you pull out the inside with a bamboo stickfried ricesataay (chiken, pork, beef)etc etc etcWe also had coconut drink (the actual coconut the size of my face) and sugar cane drink. They were both gooooooood. Yum. I'm a sugar cane fan now.I think this was all good because we had the locals order and teach us how to enjoy the dishes. If it was me and other non-locals, I think we would have been ripped off with the cost (I hear that can happen). At least for me, now I know which shop I should order from next time I go (sorry, the colleague's uncle's shop was a bit far and I didn't check the name of his shop.)

E7gvLCkTQXf7J3R1LbM1uA.text: Be careful here - this is a tourists trap. All food is of a low quality and overpriced. Locals never visit this place and prefer other hawker centres.

VLnMcP0I89g2Iut8hBNJQA.text: Really great place to get a meal, particularly in the evening when the heat is not oppressive. We ordered jumbo prawns, vegetables and other local favs from Sin Sin Seafood BQ (stall 66) and were very pleased. The shrimp are massive and nicely broiled, without all the yucky chili oil that is lathered on at many restaurants. You can also find lobster, chicken skewers and pretty much anything else you'd like. Service was great - the lady from the beer stall kept stopping by whenever we were needed a new bottle. And the price can't be beat. Overall a great experience, though I subtract 1* for the somewhat annoying hawkers/touts. Yes, I know that's what they get paid to do, but that doesn't make it any less irritating to be hassled as you walk by every single store. Easy to find off the Newton MRT stop.

-gXVa69xORCIfC1oDFSUqQ.text: An easy way to get all the local delights under 1 roof- indian rojak, BBQ stingray, murtabak, satay, etc. It's overpriced, there're too many tourists, but it's still tasty and convenient

zOoYk0A4zDsZm1gwoVwh1Q.text: With endless food options in Singapore, Newton Food Centre feels pretty mediocre.  As with any other hawker centre (aka food courts), Newton has plenty of seating, a decent variety of food, and prices are pretty standard.  It's outdoor seating, so it might not be the first place I'd choose if it's raining or if it's sweltering - just a thought. I just don't really like hawker centers ha!

W1cP-QLZD3gWbTYBrmo3Eg.text: Very interesting. Lots of Singapore street food and seafood. Is a great tourist destination.

wB_ihyod3wjtl0ySG_ucGg.text: I visited Newton Hawker Center on 26th Feb and at 730pm, the car park was almost full and the parking attendant was making his rounds and issuing parking fines! Do note, they do not have a gantry system, so have your parking coupons ready!There are a lot of BBQ Seafood stalls in Newton and most of them sell the same stuff. Do note that though they tout and push each shop, every customer has the right to say NO! The touters get commission based on what they sell to you. To avoid getting cheated, pay upon ordering and INSIST so, else you might end up with a 3 digit bill at the end of your meal, with no explanation.Here's a review of the food we shared amongst 6 people, 4 of which were yelpers :)The Ocean BBQ  #01-016 We just picked the stall we sat right next too, but I did notice that the stalls facing the inner circle seemed to be more popular. This ocean BBQ, is one of the outside stalls facing the car park.1. Lemon Chicken $15I loved lemon chicken and we ordered this. Expecting to be a thick chicken cutlet, I was surprised to see it served as fried cubed chicken. Some pieces were of the thigh meat, hence more flavourful, some pieces were breast meat and very dry. The sauce itself was decent, very lemony and you can taste the slight blend of honey. But I guess having cubed-sized chicken makes it easier for sharing.2. Sambal Singray $15Jie Ying mentioned that the sambal was nice and it was! It was slightly sweet and for someone like me who doesn't eat spicy. This was the perfect sambal stingray for me! The stingray was meaty and the meat was easily separated from the bones. 3. Sambal SotongA similar sauce from the stingray was stir fried with the sotong, hence making the sotong abit sweet. The sotong tasted fresh and the serving was big enough for the 6 of us to share. Chances is, I might hit this stall up again, the next time I'm here. Definitely in love with their sambal!Bedok 85 Fried Oyster #01-0401. Oyster Omelette $5They were very generous with the oysters, The egg was crispy on the top layer, but on the bottom layer, it was soggy and was very mushy. I didn't quite like it in the end. If you want really good oyster omelette, try Kim Keat at Bradell.2. Carrot Cake White/black $4Even though their sign boards still says the carrot cakes are sold in $3 portions, They have increased their prices. The black had alot more egg and was sweet. The white wasn't crispy and tasted bland. Overall, another upsetting local dishKwang Huat #01-015 Steffenie was patiently waiting for this stall to open at 745pm! And at 730pm the owners were ready to take orders, but we didn't get our food till about 750pm.1. Hokkien Prawn Mee $5For $5, you get a satisfying plate of prawn mee with a lot of gravy, and 4 big prawns. The gravy is truly tasty and yummy. Although you can tell they did not use any lard, so it's missing that special taste. Some sotong and egg is what you get with the prawn mee, no three-layer pork meat either. I guess this stall is now muslim-friendly. 2. Char Kway Teow This was a rather OK dish at best. I couldn't taste the wok-hei and there were a lot of cockles and no other ingredients, there were like 2 slices of 50 cent coin sized fish cakes.. I do not like cockles, so I found this very upsetting. Char Kway teow to me is my most favourite dish in Singapore but I wouldn't come back here for this.Singa Cafe #01-014 Their sugar juice drinks are $1.50 and can drinks are priced at $1.50. Very reasonable pricingSoursop Juice $2I loved that their soursop juice was full of soursup meat. The drink was served with a plastic spoon, which you will need to scoop up the fruit.For those unknown to the benefits of soursop.Soursop contains a number of natural substances that have biological benefits such as, relieve stomach distress, fever, pain and respiratory problems such as cough and asthma.TKR #01-030 After walking around, we realized the prices were standard for the chicken wings $1.30 and 60cents per satay. We decided to go with TKR as it was a chinese stall, which meant they sold pork satay!1. Pork/chicken/mutton Satay 60 cents eachWe ordered 10 sticks of pork, 10 sticks of chicken and 10 sticks of mutton which added up to $18, and they gave us 5 bowls of satay sauce. The pork satay had alot of fats in them, which for me, I actually enjoyed. For the health conscious, you might want to just take the chicken sticks, which were more tender. The mutton was considerably drier than the chicken and pork, but it didn't have the weird smell. So I was okay with it.2. BBQ Chicken wings $1.30 eachThe chicken wings were pretty good. I enjoyed the crispy roasted skin. The meat was very juicy and I felt that for BBQ chicken wings, these weren't too oily and is a good choice for me! I've had BBQ chicken wings dripping with oil and that's usually the reason why I avoid them.They were presented very nicely on the styrofoam plate. They definitely gave some thought into present

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. TKR #01-030
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. TKR #01-030
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. TKR #01-030

fQKX-Ido5eYw5PJlG2C2Iw.text: Good food, great value, friendly service and relatively quick. Just my kind of place. I grew up with street food and places like this were my staple growing up. I love the vibe and the no frills ambience and great tasting food.  As we were staying with friends close to this place we decided to check it out. This is quite a big open air food centre with quite a selection of food and drinks to choose from. Give the shops your table number and they deliver the food right to you and collect payment :-) There is a huge selection of seafood on offer, noodles, Indian and Malaysian food and of course my favourite childhood drink, sugarcane juice :-))) Loved the flavours and the taste and we had food from over 5 stalls here to share. Happily come here anyday for a feed. If nothing else its a great place to people watch and sip a drink.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Fried rice
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Aloo paratha
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Chilli crab

5G2bLmS1yZMwTNH9PfQdQQ.text: The vendors here are AGGRESSIVE.  Every one sells more or less the same items but beware of getting ripped off.Some things I would recommend:-Freshly squeezed juice (soursop since you can't get that in the states)-Cereal prawns-Oyster pancake-Fish cake wrapped in a leaf-Chicken skewers-Chicken wingsEven though it's a hawker center, I wouldn't expect to pay any less than you would at a normal restaurant.  Food is still yummy though.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Lychee drink

byEBg2CjhwUV171rP6Mclg.text: There are just too many good food centers in Singapore, with top notch hawkers dishing out food you will always go back for, despite a long line. With such competition around, Newton Circus is just one of many and has the misfortune to be seen as a tourist trap. It did not help that there used to be touts (maybe there still are?) from the seafood stalls (usually) targeting and annoying the diners who may just want to browse first before deciding on what to order. The only good thing about Newton Circus is that it is opened till very late at night and used to be my one of my "go to" places for supper after clubbing. I never knew it is also open in the day time until a few years ago. I think day time stalls cater more to the people working or studying in the area, as well as those heading to Malaysia. There is a causeway link bus leaving from the car park which takes people across to JB. So in the wee hours of the morning, at least one stall will be open (the bak chor mee stall facing the car park is open 24 hours) to serve customers who need sustenance before their trip to Malaysia or heading to work. By 8 am, more stalls will be open (mostly those facing the car park) - bak chor mee stall, Malay stall and a few drinks stall. From 11 am, the stalls on the row facing the car park will all be open, plus a few other stalls facing the inner court yard area, to cater to the lunch crowd. The seafood and bbq chicken wings stalls are mostly open in the evening. The stalls I usually frequent:Fish soup: all the 3 stalls are good with fresh fish. - stall facing car park, next to Thai stall -- very fresh fish slices but cost much more than the others. Also serve tang hoon fish ball soup.- stall facing car park, towards the end near Malay stall -- better for fried fish soup with milk- stall behind of the row facing car park, next to Indian drinks stall -- also food for fresh fish slice soup with no milk. Duck stall (yu kee I think) facing car park -- one my of favorite place for duck porridge (only $3 which is cheap for Newton pricing) and duck kway teow or set. The soup is herbal and the stallholder is very generous about giving refills. The chili is fantastic with fried crispy ikan bilis in it. For the Malay stalls, I prefer the corner one nearer to the bus stop along Bukit Timah road. It has one of the cheapest nasi padang around. The corner Malay stall facing the car park is pricier and generally attracts more customers because of the location. The sardine curry puff and fried chicken wing are good though. The popiah stall facing the car park is Hokkien style and is something of an acquired preference. I only like it after trying it a few times. You need to order a minimum of 2 rolls and is open a bit later in the day, after 1230 pm or so. The Thai stall is open closer to 12 pm and is very popular. You will need to wait for a while. It has pretty good Thai food like the usual pad thai, basil chicken rice, etc. The tom yam soup is not that nice though. The nasi lemak stall near the Thai food is fairly new and is overpriced and not that good. For a small plate of fried beehoon with a tiny piece of luncheon meat, it cost $3. The chili is of the Maggi variety. The highly recommended fried chicken is also not worth it. Just normal. Fruit juice and fresh fruits are better at the stall facing the car park. Pricing is ok too, when compared to Orchard area. Hot and Cold Dessert stall facing the car park is another hot favorite for many. Pricing is also of the affordable type, cheaper than food court in the malls. In general, I think the stalls which are opened during the day has reasonable hawker pricing and you will not think they are overpriced at all. I think the bad rep for Newton Circus hawkers about over-charging is usually referred to the seafood BBQ stalls or those stalls which are open at night.

RGGVwp-H3YnAU0a0HzfwmA.text: Pretty good hawker center, I liked that it is just around the corner from the MRT station.Came on Sunday morning and it was pretty dead but this was my first time seeing places offer Sting Ray so that was impressive. $12 is quite a splurge but I really enjoyed it, tasty and not greasy at all like your typical hawker fare.It was annoying that I could only find lemon tea in cans. What's that all about?

b2kZtA2lye8n5G1ZVZqGLw.text: I don't understand why this place has such a low rating. This place was just what I needed. I mean, what were you expecting? You're outside, in a food court. Someone's there to  take your order, bring your food, clean up after you eat. I guess you can go up to the individual shacks and order, but why go through all that trouble. Cereal Prawns?Check. Chili Crab? Check. Crispy whole fish?Please!Fried rice?OMG yes.Lemon Chicken?Bring it.Came here around 9:30 at night and was easily seated, easily served. Everyone is given prepackaged plates, utensils, napkins. Food was served quickly and served hot. Not pipping hot, but hot enough. Probably the best meal I experienced in Singapore. Everywhere else is just to modernized for me. Just give me no frills tummy loving good grub!

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

hvEN4fzFCnt0IdBLPKbN7g.text: I have been here couple times and never like it cos it food is more expensive than other centres and most stores are selling mainly seafoods and satays. Rarely see local go there and mainly tourists.Recently renovated but can't tell the different.

_nTv9KrAkyuuGBCGRowE9A.text: Well, I simply could not get enough of these food halls, so when I got off the MRT station at Newton to visit a street named after my namesake, I knew I had to go and check this place out. Okay, it is a bit out of the way, and there is nothing around here that I am aware of that would cause anybody to come here (unless it is to check out the hawker's market) but it was still worth it. Well, when I was here it was still reasonably early on a Monday morning, so most of the shops were closed, but there were still enough for me to partake in some of the offerings. As can be expected, there are quite a few stall, and even though it was raining, there were still enough undercover seats for me to sit at.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

C3Dzl79wutdUXxSrRsLSbQ.text: Whenever I manage to make it back to Singapore, I would always make sure to stop by this food centre.  It is one of the best places to sample the diversity that is local Singaporean food at a relatively cheap price!Conveniently located just steps away from the Newton MRT, and one train stop from Orchard Road, this place has become really popular among tourists.  It is also one of the bigger and cleaner food centres around.My favorite dishes to get here are stingray in chili, oyster fried eggs, sugar canes and  BBQ chicken wings.  Their satay and roti john are pretty good too.  Prices are more expensive than the typical "local" food centre (again, since it's a tourist hot spot), but the quality and taste of the food is superb!Tips:* go in the evenings to avoid eating out in Singapore heat, and with more stalls being open, it's livelier :)* open all night too!

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Fish head curry
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Oyster omelette.

FAqueqOkM8v-gKFfAG01FQ.text: If you're visiting Singapore, you can't miss out on going to a hawker center. Now this one here is more tourist oriented since it's near the touristy area. This means that1. It's more pricey2. You don't get as much The stalls here sell a variety of Singaporean foods. When you first come in you just sit down on a table and either go up to a stall and order something or people will come up to you. They're pretty aggressive in selling their food. Some sellers will help you find a table (but they expect that you buy food from their stall in return). You might as well let them do the work for you though. At worst they'll just be a bit unhappy.Food that you should try here: 1. Oyster Pancake - A egg like mixture with fresh oysters. 2. Sugar Cane with Lemon (Drink) - freshly ground sugar cane with lemon yum. 3. Chili Crab4. Stingray - If you can tolerate spiciness make sure to smear the entire thing with chili. It's not very flavorful by itself.

Q0aAaQ482ZcQt5WUzEdYAg.text: So.... What's the big deal? What's with all the hype? After spending a few days in Singapore, we visited this hawker center for dinner on our last night, based on reviews and recommendations. The stars it gets are due to the fact that I loved the food at every hawker I visited, and Newton was no different. Let me lay out the negatives... - these vendors were the most aggressive I dealt with while in Singapore. It made the experience a bit less enjoyable. - this hawker center is seafood focused, and by that I mean bbq stingray. Everyone gets that here. If you love it, cool, but itdidn't suit my taste. Didn't hate it. Just didn't love it.- because this Center is focused on seafood, it's missing a lot of the variety of the other ones. Conclusion: if you want to try some bbq stingray, fried carrot cake, or oyster omelette, this is the place to do it. If not, you may want to try another hawker where the vendors are less aggressive and there is more food variety.

Nl_SEtlqx27TPnKfz8wrDA.text: This is a really good starter hawker center for people who are new to Singapore/the hawker center life. I recently brought some friends from the states who had never been to Asia here. They were overwhelmed to say the least- imagine if I had taken them to somewhere less ang moh friendly. Yes, because it's a little more tourist oriented it is a little more expensive, but it has a good array of food- satay to seafood and more. Also, they are really great about making sure you do not go without tiger beer. The best thing here is definitely the sambal stingray. as most reviewers mentioned. One big tip: they sometimes try to rip you off and you can get sticker shock when the bill comes. I try to pay for my dishes ASAP and buy beer one bottle at a time. This ensures you're keeping track of what you're spending. Happy eating in Singapore!

DgUDXGPteFjZoaKwWulUrw.text: Newton Circus - the famous food centre for tourists. Prices here are definitely higher than your typical hawker centre/ neighborhood food centre due to it being a popular tourist destination. Nonetheless, I wouldnt say that the quality of food is compromised.Service here is surprisingly good. There are stall helpers helping you find a table... but they may also pressure you to ordering from them. They are pretty active in coming up to you and asking for your order, but you can simply say no. Ventilation here is also decent. Close proximity to town, so I definitely recommend bringing foreign friends here to try the local fare, especially since Gluttons Bay can get really crowded at times.

8P3mtDN09uS_8uWyYi53VQ.text: My bf and I came here on a Tuesday afternoon to check out a real hawker center and were surprised to find it a little bit dead with many stalls closed.  I thought it would be bustling all day long, but perhaps all the action takes place at night?I was really hesitant at first, because the vendors were really pushy, and the place looked a bit run-down and dirty, but we settled on a guy who waved a wriggly crab at us.  We ordered a chili crab (male, because we weren't quite sure how to eat a female), spicy kang kong, black pepper beef, fried rice, and a large bottle of Tiger beer to share.Surprisingly, the food was DELICIOUS.  I normally don't like the taste of chili, but the crab was really fresh and yummy.  There is something to be said for seafood that is still alive when you order it.My only regret is that we omitted the mantou (steamed bread) due to the fried rice order.  We should have gotten mantou to sop up all the chili crab sauce.So lesson learned:  Looks may be deceiving.  Despite the initial letdown due to the grungy exterior and plastic and styrofoam dishware, the food turned out to be fantastic!!  AND DON'T FORGET THE MANTOU!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Yummy chili crab, black pepper beef, kang kong, and fried rice at Newton hawker center!
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

vFFmMbrMBqRJb4BKZtPerQ.text: Hawker food is a specialty that one has to try when coming to Singapore. Newton Food Center is one of those places that is located near touristic areas, so it's not 100% the real deal (you get that if you have locals taking you by car to more distant food centers), but it's very close to the way it should be.I have always found the food to be great, and I do not complain about prices being a little higher than the standard Hawker food places, after all I am not a local and it's cheaper than eating in other restaurants. "Must tries" are the stingray, the sugar cane drinks, the chili crabs, but generally as you pick the food that is served to you, anything that picks your fancy is a good choice!

ZbfG6wVDVuUD_TNB1Zsebg.text: Newton Food Center used to be so good. When I was growing up, they had one of the best of everything that represented Singapore hawker scene. Now it's a sucky tourist destination.Part of the reason is that they stopped using pork lard in their cooking. This is to cater to the huge influx of Muslim tourist from the region.Really nothing against Muslims, just saying the food isn't the same. Pork lard is essential in Chinese cooking. Like ghee is to Indian cooking. We have a saying, "No lard, no good".But the main reason is the high rental cost. Lots of the original hawkers left and sub-leased the stall.There's still a few good stalls but most of them is crap. Go to Old Airport or East Coast Lagoon instead.

l7_whAb7kF1V6z9rH_S8Gg.text: Loved the food  A real Singapore experience.  Just down the road from our old apartmrent so visited all the time

XB_yi0MqS7N1PdilJggrfQ.text: I did a yelp to see what restaurants were nearby. This popped up as being very close to our hotel at the Sheraton Towers.  Hubby was under the weather as he caught a bad cold after our two week cruise that started and ended in Singapore.  I thought to order room service but did I want to pay $25 SGD for a burger?So I drag hubby along to Newton's.  Now this is what hawking food is all about.  Menus being pushed under our noses.   Eat here.  Eat here.  We settled on a noodle place.  We ordered and he asked what table number are we at.  We asked table number?  The idea is to grab a table first.  You pay after your food is brought to you.  What I noticed later about most food courts including this one is that there are sinks where you can wash your hands before and after you eat.  This food court is the epitome of all food courts.  Read about it in Wikipedia.

kcdaqfPmTEE7QNG1rEMGzw.text: She got wings, she got a haloIt seems to me so unnaturalCause there's one thing, that I just don't knowWhat seemed to be so incredible at..NEWTON HAWKER CENTER! - Akon (angel)If you want to be Rachel Chu for a day, you're definitely coming here! From Crazy Rich Asians to Top Chef, this is the hawker center that I would recommend if you could only pick one. There's so many tourists here (including myself) and it has a great energy to it with excellent lighting and clean tables. The guy selling us the chili crab also actively was looking for tables. There's numbers on each table so you just order and tell them what number your table is and they will bring it to you. Most of them you don't pay until they come to you but some you pay up front. It's so much fun going around the different stands, what an experience!I tried the chili crab, some chicken skewers (local fav), a local "burrito" that they made with rice paper and pad thai noodles made to order, oyster pancake (my least fav), and of course sugar cane juice. This very friendly guy asked me if I wanted it with lemon and he said it was even better so I ordered it and it was soooo good. From the rest of the trip on, I only ordered it with lemon haha yeah super awesome!The hustle is real here (same with all hawker centers) but I did some research and wrote down the stall numbers on my phone so I knew where I was going. I think when they realized I was on a mission to find certain stalls, they let me be hahaA few tips: try to avoid peak hours if possible and also try to come on a weekday. It is outdoors so if it rains (which happens a few hours everyday in Singapore), there's very few tables with umbrellas on them. Most of the dessert places close early so don't expect to find dessert here. (that's ok lots of other places to go to!) Did I mention try the sugar cane juice with lemon? Best hawker center that I've tried in Singapore - Rachel Chu mission: part 1 check!

4wqnp701q-LLGUDdkWvhjA.text: Great hawker center when the weather is nice.  Plenty of seating and lots of ceiling fans, great place to be on a nice night for dinner.  Tables and chairs were also very clean.  Staff are quick to clean tables when someone leaves.  Loved the BBQ crab, grilled sting ray, etc.Looks like all of the restaurants and juice stands sell pretty much the same items at similar prices.  I don't recall the name of the restaurant but it was the seafood place right next to the walkway coming on from the parking lot.

q5Li70BIMXWjIQb0A2jLZw.text: Came here in my first night at Singapore and I enjoyed a lot of its night market food style. You can order multiple items from most of the stalls. These are: meat, seafood, and other skewers; sausage; mantis; fried shrimp; beer; sugar cane juice; veggies; naans; fried noodles; and many more. However, the food can be a bit greasy if you are not used to it. In addition, there can be fight for seating from time to time as the number of seating can be very limited. But these shouldn't hold you back from coming to this place to eat a wonderful dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

6TJ-wsJLS2BYVRuiLQUPCA.text: While Newton tends to be a bit more touristy than other hawker centers, I love the cereal prawn and don't mind the constant beckoning from the other aunties and uncles attending to their stalls ;). Be prepared though, if heckling bothers you go elsewhere.Come with friends and enjoy an assortment of dishes from the various stalls. It's conveniently located near an MRT station too.

530WdNREp5nr6zDSs6RAxQ.text: Much better hawkers in Singapore, bait and switch , buy the photos of food and eat elsewhere. Lau pa Sat , main tourist trap. But it's also in middle of central business district packed with locals. Much better food and value.

tl-e4svTSY6U_8PYMKebNg.text: In Crazy Rich Asians, where's the first place Nick and Rachel hit up? Newton Food Centre. It's an open air hawker center just above Newton station on the Downtown MRT Line. Despite it being outdoors, the environment appeared very clean and well kept, a significant notch above Lau Pa Sat and Maxwell I loved the service. In spite of initially not wanting to order from one Seafood stall, the auntie there offered to distribute my order to the respective neighboring stalls, so it was essentially table service through a charitable restauranteur. A good selection of Oyster Scramble, Tulang Steak and other Muslim foods are outstanding selections of this Hawker Center in particular.

bb53mJ4keIqqL5nm7zbLOA.text: Consistent and delicious Chicken or Tofu Laksa and the Mini wok noodle with side of soup. You must give this place a try during breakfast, lunch, and dinner time. Dinner time this center is packed with people from local to tourists. The Fish soup stall is to die for too which is about 3 stalls to the left of the Chicken Laksa stall.It's worth coming here at the Newton subway stop.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. This is the stand for the Best Chicken Laksa.
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Mini wok noodle with side broth is so delicious
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Delicious Chicken or tofu laksa

B-i2GM1jJvZuJWqNTjEZIA.text: Newton Hawker Centre is one of the larger centres in Singapore with lots of food options to choose from. It is also the centre with more staff approaching patrons with menus and one to one sales techniques. I opted for the imfamous Soon Wah Fishball and Bee Heng Popiah! Soon Wah Fishballs are made in the traditional Teochew way. Each ball is handmade, kneaded for bounce and airyness. Fish meat is gentlely folded in, thereafter. Fish dumplings (probably best fish dumplings in Singapore and probably in life) are made from fish paste wrappers with meat filling. Each bowl is topped with crispy lard for texture and flavour! Yum! Soon Wah deserves to be in the Fishballs hall of fame!Bee Heng Popiah is also a legend in this hawker centre. Soft thin crepes are filled with combination of ingredients including bean a sprouts, lettuce leaves etc. It is sweet and savory with crisp texture. This centre is what hawker legends are made of! If you love food, you must visit Newton Hawker Centre!

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

z3ghkdNnQqwmyGUE_bvZGg.text: Went here last night... although tired and very sleep deprived... the star attraction of the night was the crab! Was very tempted to order soooo much more... Chillie Crab $36SG for 700gram from seafood alliance... $3 for the marn tdou bun.. my ping ting is non existent..  it was medium size crab enough for 2.  Meat was fresh nice and firm. But definitely can not compare to the Australian Darwin mud crab!!! which is more flavourful. Well IMHO was good but i don't think is the best... the sauce / gravy was a bit too sweat.. over the years of coming in and out of SG I still haven't found a "WOW" Have been coming here on and off over the years and SG and I still haven't found a place that I can say... YEP I WOULD DEFINITELY RETURN for the crab. Any friendly yelpers out there with good suggestions... ideas most welcomed! :)) Chicken wing... wooooah!!! I'd come back for that alone!! Maaaan it was right size and had the chargrill flavour.. add the lime provided and a little dip into that sauce!!! Wooow! Overall it was a great experience washed down with a large bottle of Tiger for $7.50SG!! The growling jungle beats playing in my stomach due to hunger was very quickly replaced by carnivale!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Chillie Crab $39SG from seafood alliance...
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Hokkien mee...  naaaah KL better
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

ctJ1__YcC_SfAk0wwrT26g.text: This is a food court located right near Novena circle and is probably the most affordable food court near Orchard road (aka Times Square and Fifth Avenue of Singapore). you can find local eats here for a decent price and it maintains much of Singapores authentic original flavors. Highly recommend the duck dark rice.  It is a good place to go in the evening and has fares such as satay, black pepper crab, duck rice, chicken rice, fish porridge, and other famous fares. I had the dark duck rice- if you like Hainanese chicken rice, then you want this dish- it is a darker dish than Hainanese chicken which has that chickeny taste that you can tell has a garlicky and simpler taste of chicken, but the duck rice has a hint of sweet, more herbs, and that heavier taste of duck that differentiates Chicken from duck. I personally love duck and if you like Peking Duck, then consider this dish. It is a Singaporean version of Peking duck over rice with a side of herbal soup (not a fan of the herbal too sweet aftertaste soup). It is not too heavy and is pleasant to the senses.batang fish porridge is also a must have for people who like their congees- the fish porridge is not so much congee but rather a fish soup poured over cooked rice but you:re really here to try to sweet flavor of mackerel that is what makes this soup really have that fishy but oceany taste that makes this dish great for either one who:s tired of the heavier dishes in Singaporean fare or wants comfort food. You cant go wrong with other Singaporean fares that I listed above if you:re new to singaporean food. For locals, this is an alright stall- a little higher on the price side and the hawkers are a little pushy and will pressure you to buying drinks and stuff. The prices are cash only for tourists and can be priced highly compared to other local hawker centers around Singapore. Leave your dishes when you:re done, someone will clean. bring your own napkins and cash to pay for your food.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Duck rice

5b_GdwK9L6z5hXCwYscwSA.text: Recently renovated. Lots of stalls with variety of foods. Got the pepper crab but didnt enjoy the flavour - the meat itself was good however. The satay beef and chicken was their best food item in my opinion

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

NEcC0Q4pvjQDFfOjX91Z4A.text: Great hawker center, definitely one of my favorites. There are quite a few stalls here. I had some satay, chicken noodle dish, samosas and mango snow ice (my favorite!). Everything was so yummy. I liked this place because you gave them your table number and they would deliver the food to you. Like most hawker centers this one is pretty inexpensive and there's some great people watching. Overall, a good afternoon spent, definitely recommend a stop by, it's right near the Newtown metro stop.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Lime juice
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Mango snow ice
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Roti set & samosa

sXAQWuIsjsw-2uEVJ-ulJg.text: My favorite was oyster omelette from heng stall no.28 and bbq stingray from all best grilled seafood stall no.39..CONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED!!

JNMCrIUiyxOqEC3D8G5a4Q.text: Eeeeep. Not the nicest hawker centre around, and DEFINITELY not a good hawker centre for a vegetarian!I came here to meet friends and figured I'd be able to find at least one or two things suitable to eat, because so far Singapore has been ridiculous easy for me to navigate as a vegan. But hawker centres can be trickier, and this one was definitely the least vegan-friendly (let alone vegetarian-friendly) hawker centre that I came across.Plus I felt hassled by all the food vendors. I mean, yeah, I get it, they're hawkers, they're gonna hawk -- but they all seemed more aggressive here than anywhere else. I walked around in endless circles, trying to find something (ANYTHING!) non-meat and non-seafood to eat, and as a white person I kept getting asked, "You want fried rice? You want fried rice?" It was kinda funny but mildly insulting at the same time. Just because I'm white doesn't mean I want plain fried rice because I can't handle spicy or exotic foods.Finally, I grabbed a lychee drink (overpriced) and managed to find one lonely vegetarian plate on offer at an Indian stall. It was a curry (I specified no ghee and they grunted something that I assumed was acquiescence -- maybe they don't use much ghee here, I dunno). It was super-spicy (thank God someone sensed that my pasty complexion belies a spice-loving interior -- or more likely they just didn't care). It was actually pretty yummy, but more expensive than anticipated, and the lady that made it was sweating buckets over the stove, rings of sweat under her armpits, so I felt like my dish may have come with a tangy human-sweat aftertaste, but whatever.There were also pillars of smoke billowing everywhere, which was making a lot of people (I'm talking actual locals, not precious tourists) cough and wave their tissues in the air in front of them.Really not a pleasant hawker centre experience. There are better ones in Singapore. ESPECIALLY if you're vegetarian (much less vegan).

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

gx4A47dLngrhqKbj9AUaQw.text: Decent hawker right off the Newton MRT. I like that it is open-air and spacious. The soliciting can get a bit annoying but a strong "no" gets the message across in most cases. Because of its close proximity to Orchard Road, it's a good option for a cheap meal.

Qpz3VvaYe6kKzSlcKAugbw.text: This food center became my girlfriend and my local normal spot. There was even a week where we came here every night for the entire week, we just love it here so much.My favorite stalls are #43 for their grilled black pepper tiger prawns and pretty much all of their seafood and fried rice, and stall #46 for their Indian food. Sometimes I get the tiger prawns without any topping and dip it in the Butter chicken curry. The curry from stall #46 is surprisingly sweet and many of my friends who don't like curry can actually eat this one with some good naan bread from them.Love it here and will keep coming back!

fmgH9ibauKFEw1HsCHfdCw.text: I was super excited to land in Singapore and couldn't wait to hit up some of the local eatery.  My taxi driver suggested I go to Newton as we passed by because that's where all the locals eat and since it was pretty much within walking distance from the hotel I thought why not?My first impression of SGP was man it's hella hot and humid here!  It's crazy to walk outside in the sun but my stomach was leading the way.  It was my first introduction to what is known as "Hawker stands".  These are small restaurants the size of a public storage shed that sells cooked food for cheap prices (cash only) while you dine on shared tables in the courtyard.  All the food prices are all competitive so other than looking for a specific dish, there's no real need to compare prices.  I really wanted to try these gigantic prawns and saw them advertised at $8/100 grams.  Ok gimme two and and a small plate of Cha Kway Teow.  My total came to $37 SGP which equates to about $27 usd.  Later when I was introduced to the better hawker stands, I realized how much I been ripped off by Newton.  The locals pay no more than say $15 SGP and that includes a drink!  My friends told me that Newton is frequented by tourists which was the exact opposite from what the taxi driver told me.  There are over 100 Hawker Centers in Singapore and once I was introduced to these better ones, I would never think of coming back here for overpriced food.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore. Couldn't wait to try these.
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

biuIdQQ5RzDq_-TxGPovXg.text: Setting foot into Newton Circus Food Centre within the first 10 minutes can be a little overwhelming... Not because there are so many food & beverage vendors to choose from, but because you are constantly being solicited by vendors left and right to try their food. It's good to take a quick walk around the food center and see all the food stalls before deciding what to order. You'll notice that they sell a lot of the same stuffs with slightly different variations. I got the sour sop juice and was not impressed. The grilled stingray--fresh, but the spice was not particularly unique. The food center is a great place to meet and hang with a large group of friends over late night snack. But not a spot for quality food.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

Ig2kvy0lybKMxRuJTdmlgA.text: My favourite food court. An open space with several tiny stalls offering their specialties. Good place to enjoy traditional seafood in many varieties. Also satay is a "must have" at Newton Circus Food Centre. Explore this lovely place in the evening. It is really enjoyable.

photos.caption: Photo of Newton Circus Food Centre - Singapore, Singapore

yM--NRhCZQRJGDOtalY7og.text: This is actually one of my least favorite hawker centers and it has little to do with the quality of the food. Many of the stalls here do a great job and serve very good food and I like the round design of the place which gives a nice overview.The issue here is however that people constantly bother you and trying to get you to order stuff. I mean if I sit with my food I do not want to be interrupted every 30 seconds by some placing a menu in front of me, asking me to order or even worse just trying to place a plate in front of me and pretend I ordered it. I was actually a bit surprised as I even had to tell one guy really harshly to stop bothering us. Also then saw the same guy screw some tourists that did not have the same sense out of 25 SGD for a plate of carrot cake.Perhaps unfair to all the good places here but I just find myself annoyed when I go here. I still occasionally go as friends live close by but then we usually take the food with us to avoid all the people bothering us.
